B3_rubric_calibration.description: Systematic calibration of beta multiplier X ∈ [0.5, 2.0] using B.3 rubric dimensions

dimensions.rationale: Market cap ~USD 56MM (BRL 326MM). Micro-cap by US standards, small-cap in Brazil. Illiquid trading (avg volume 35K shares). Scores near max on size risk.
82% revenue Brazil (EM), 14% USA. Argentina subsidiary in hyperinflationary economy. Currency exposure (BRL/USD volatility). Above-average EM risk but not frontier market.
In midst of strategic pivot from CPaaS/SaaS mix to SaaS-only. CPaaS revenue declining with margin erosion. SaaS unproven at scale. High execution uncertainty.

Negative working capital BRL -444MM, going concern risk acknowledged. Covenant breaches requiring waivers. Net debt BRL 60MM + BRL 271MM acquisition liabilities vs BRL 88MM EBITDA. Dependent on asset sale to avoid distress.
CPaaS: weak position in commoditized market, margins collapsing. SaaS: early mover in Brazil CX but facing global competitors (Salesforce, HubSpot). Modest competitive moat.

Founder-CEO aligned but recent CFO change, CHRO/CTO departures. Controlling shareholders (Bobsin/Oria) supportive but also potentially conflicted. Execution track record mixed (successful M&A integration but margin miss).
Mature CPaaS business (declining). SaaS in early scaling phase (23% growth). Not startup but not mature. Moderate growth risk.

EBITDA positive but gross margin compressed. Revenue mix volatile. Heavy adjustments (normalized EBITDA excludes earn-out, severance). Tax loss carryforwards mask cash tax reality. Moderate earnings quality issues.

adjustments.rationale: Going concern risk and covenant breaches warrant additional premium beyond financial health score
Execution risk of CPaaS exit and SaaS scaling warrants incremental premium
Double-counting risk: size and geography already scored high; avoid over-penalizing. X should be elevated but not punitive.

aggregate_score.note: Raw average 1.60 + adjustments (+0.10 liquidity, +0.05 pivot, -0.30 double-count) = 1.45. This reflects elevated risk profile (small EM ADR in transition with liquidity stress) but not distressed/terminal level.

Higher risk case (pivot stumbles, liquidity worsens)

discount_rate_sensitivities.note: DR most sensitive to X calibration (business-specific risk) and Brazil RFR (sovereign/inflation risk). ERP assumed stable at 6.5%.

WACC_comparison.note: Implied WACC ~20.6% consistent with elevated risk profile. Post-divestiture WACC would decline to ~16-18% as leverage normalizes and business model stabilizes.

peer_comparison.rationale: ZENV DR 22% vs LatAm tech median ~15%. 700 bps premium justified by: (1) micro-cap illiquidity, (2) going concern risk, (3) strategic transition execution risk. Peers (MercadoLibre, VTEX, STNE) are larger, more established, better capitalized.

reasonableness_check.note: DR 22% - terminal growth 4.5% = 17.5% perpetuity discount = ~5.7x EV/EBITDA terminal multiple. Reasonable for small EM SaaS company if pivot succeeds.

recommendation.rationale: 22% BRL DR reflects elevated risk profile across all dimensions: micro-cap, EM exposure, strategic pivot, liquidity stress, competitive uncertainty. X=1.45 calibrated systematically via B.3 rubric, landing in 1.2-1.5 range expected for small EM/ADR companies. DR will likely decline to 18-19% post-divestiture if pivot succeeds (improved financial health, simplified business model, larger equity cushion). Current DR appropriate for valuing uncertain transition period cash flows.
key_sensitivities: X calibration (business-specific risk): ±0.25 moves DR by ±160 bps
Brazil RFR (sovereign/inflation): ±140 bps moves DR by ±140 bps
Strategic pivot success: Could justify DR reduction to 18% by 2027-2028
